discussion.content: A is correct root event dataset - When creating a data model in Splunk, there is one root dataset that requires at least one constraint. That dataset is the "events" dataset, which represents all the raw events in your data.

Selected Answer: A
A : A Root Event Dataset in a data model must have at least one constraint, typically a base search (index=... or a similar filtering condition). This ensures that the dataset retrieves relevant events efficiently.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct. Unlike event or transaction datasets, which store all data, search datasets must filter results based on at least one condition to avoid retrieving excessive data.
A is correct, Pg.236

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

questions.question_text: Which search retrieves events with the event type web_errors?
When used with the timechart command, which value of the limit argument returns all values?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.0.4/SearchReference/Timechart
the answer is C.. Fund. 2 pg.56
C. Per Splunk, If you set limit=0, no series filtering occurs and all distinct values are used" https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/SCS/current/SearchReference/TimechartCommandSyntaxDetails
The answer is C - When used with the timechart command in Splunk, setting the limit argument to 0 (zero) will return all values for the specified time range.

choices.C: A macro is a portion of a search that can be reused in multiple places.
choices.A: A macro is a method of categorizing events based on a search.
choices.D: A macro is a way to associate an additional (new) name with an existing field name.
choices.B: A macro is a knowledge object that enables you to schedule searches for specific events.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is a better answer

Selected Answer: C
A. that is Event Type 
B. that is search
C. this is macro
D. this is alias 

C is the answer

Selected Answer: C
Macro is not knowledge object

Selected Answer: C
"Search macros are reusable chunks of Search Processing Language (SPL) that you can insert into other searches. Search macros can be any part of a search, such as an eval statement or search term, and do not need to be a complete command. You can also specify whether the macro field takes any arguments." And a macro is not a knowledge object, right?

C. Per Splunk, "Search macros can be any part of a search, such as an eval statement or search term, and do not need to be a complete command." https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/Knowledge/Definesearchmacros

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer

index=games | eval ProductSales = $Price$ * $AmountSold$

Which of the following will return results?
